title: Michael Homer
text:
Michael J. Homer (February 24, 1958 – February 1, 2009) was an American electronics and computer industry executive who played major roles in the development of the <a href="personal%20computer">personal computer</a>, <a href="mobile%20device">mobile device</a>s and the <a href="Internet">Internet</a>.
Life and career.
Homer was born in <a href="San%20Francisco">San Francisco</a> on February 24, 1958 and was awarded a bachelor's degree at the <a href="University%20of%20California%2C%20Berkeley">University of California, Berkeley</a>.
He was hired by <a href="Apple%20Inc.">Apple Computer</a> in 1982, where he served as the technology adviser to the firm's chief executive, <a href="John%20Sculley">John Sculley</a>. He followed with a position as marketing vice president at <a href="GO%20Corp.">GO Corp.</a>, an early pioneer in creating software for mobile computers and personal digital assistants that did early work in pen-based computing.
After Go closed in 1994, <a href="John%20Doerr">John Doerr</a> of <a href="Kleiner%20Perkins%20Caufield%20%26amp%3B%20Byers">Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers</a>, Go's main <a href="venture%20capital">venture capital</a> backer, made the connection for Homer at <a href="Marc%20Andreessen">Marc Andreessen</a>'s <a href="Netscape">Netscape Communications Corporation</a>. Homer was a vice president at the Netscape in the 1990s at the dawn of the <a href="World%20Wide%20Web">World Wide Web</a>. There, Homer developed the company's initial <a href="business%20plan">business plan</a> and played a pivotal role in obtaining the private financing necessary to allow the company to progress to its 1995 <a href="initial%20public%20offering">initial public offering</a>. He developed marketing plans for Netscape in 1994 at a time when few people had ever heard of the Internet. During the period where <a href="Microsoft">Microsoft</a> challenged Netscape's early browser dominance with its <a href="Internet%20Explorer">Internet Explorer</a> product, Homer headed the firm's marketing department as it faced bitter competition from Microsoft, a challenge that ultimately resulted in <a href="United%20States%20v.%20Microsoft">an antitrust suit</a>. Homer helped argue that Microsoft had abused its monopoly power in the operating system market to push out Netscape's browser in favor of its own.
Following <a href="AOL">AOL</a>'s acquisition of Netscape in 2000, Homer founded <a href="Kontiki%20%28company%29">Kontiki</a>, a peer-assisted content delivery technology company, that was purchased by <a href="VeriSign">VeriSign</a> in March 2006 for $62 million, with a proviso that the rights to use the firm's technology would be donated to the non-profit <a href="Open%20Media%20Network">Open Media Network</a>. Homer fostered the early growth of a series of technology firms, including roles in the development of <a href="Google">Google</a>, <a href="Tellme%20Networks">Tellme Networks</a> and <a href="TiVo">TiVo</a>, and sat on the board of <a href="Palm%2C%20Inc.">Palm, Inc.</a>
Illness.
In 2007, persistent memory problems he had been experiencing led to a diagnosis of <a href="Creutzfeldt%E2%80%93Jakob%20disease">Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease</a>, a very rare and incurable <a href="degeneration%20%28medical%29">degenerative</a> <a href="neurological%20disorder">neurological disorder</a>. Several people close to him created "Fight for Mike", an organization that raised $7 million used to fund research in the neurology department of the <a href="University%20of%20California%2C%20San%20Francisco">University of California, San Francisco</a> towards study and potential cure of the disease. The team at UCSF includes Dr. <a href="Stanley%20B.%20Prusiner">Stanley B. Prusiner</a>, winner of the <a href="Nobel%20Prize%20in%20Physiology%20or%20Medicine">Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine</a> in 1997 for his discovery of the <a href="prion">prion</a>, misfolded proteins that trigger CJD and <a href="bovine%20spongiform%20encephalopathy">bovine spongiform encephalopathy</a> ("mad cow disease"). The team at UCSF was studying the use of <a href="Quinacrine">Quinacrine</a>, long used as an <a href="antimalarial%20drug">antimalarial drug</a>, in the treatment of CJD.
Homer died at age 50 on February 1, 2009 in <a href="Atherton%2C%20California">Atherton, California</a>. He was survived by his wife, three children, his mother and sister. The science center at <a href="Sacred%20Heart%20Schools%2C%20Atherton">Sacred Heart Schools, Atherton</a> is named after him.
